bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frank R. McCoy, April 29, 1948

div1.p: Hench sends McCoy a memorandum on his recent trip to Cuba. Hench inquires if McCoy could arrange for Hench to use Wood's diary in the Library of Congress, and seeks further information from him concerning McCoy's opinions that Wood was the primary supporter of Reed's work in Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Frank R. McCoy, April 29, 1948
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
April 29, 1948
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
General Frank R. McCoy
1633 - 31st Street, N. W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear General McCoy:
div1.p:
I had a delightful time in Cuba. In order to organize the re-
sults of my visit and largely for my own information, I wrote out a con-
fidential memorandum which is chiefly personal; however, because of certain data
therein, I had two or three extra copies made, one to show General Kean,
one for General Truby and I should like to enclose a copy for you. You
probably will not care to read it all but may I call your attention es-
pecially to Page 10. I enclose some photographs with notes on the back and
thought you would like to have the enclosed map which may bring back memories
of former years.

General McCoy, I shall be in Washington May 11 and 12 in connection
with the International Congress on Tropical Medicine. Would it be possible
for me to spend some hours going over General Wood's diary in the Library of
Congress? Will I need a letter from you introducing me to a certain official
in the Library? I scribbled someone's name on a piece of paper in your office
before I went to Cuba but I have misplaced it in the voluminous mass of data
that I collected in Cuba. As I understood it, your secretary was going to write
General Wood's daughter and get permission for me to peruse the diary and I
should like to spend most of the afternoon of May 11, part of May 12 and pos-
sibly also part of May 13 going over the diary.

I started to write you a card from Cuba, then couldn't remember your
address. I enclose the “evidence”. In Cuba I found some old photographs. I
made photostatic copies of two of them which I enclose. The one photo was
simply labeled “General Scott and Mr. Steinhardt”. Can you identify the
officer in white? I don't imagine it is you but if it is, by all means keep
one of these photostats. Are the furnishings of the parlor in the palace
roughly as you remember them?

You will remember that I asked you to give me your opinion as to
whether General Wood actually was largely responsible for having Surgeon
General Sternberg appoint the Yellow Fever Board. This was news to me until
I saw the enclosed photostats. I would appreciate it greatly if you would
send me for my files just a comment, perhaps a paragraph on that; as I under-
stand it, you believe that General Wood did make this suggestion to Sternberg.
I hope to find corroborating evidence thereof in Wood's diary.

The other point we discussed was a statement that on two occasions
Reed was about to be recalled to Washington but Wood “saved” Reed for the
yellow fever work. I never saw that statement anywhere else and have run
across no memoranda, telegraphic or written orders or other confirmatory
data in my perusal of the records of Reed, Sternberg and others in the National
Archives

I enclose a carbon of a letter I have written to the Minister of
Public Works regarding the preservation of Camp Lazear. I hope they will
really do something about it now.

General McCoy, if you have the time and inclination, I would be
extremely grateful if you could dictate an additional paragraph of your
recollections concerning General Wood's interest in Reed's work and of your
own relationship to it as budget officer for General Wood.

Incidentally, why was the building next to General Wood's office
called the Segundo Cabo? Nobody in Cuba seems to know.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
